headline: Bjorn Lomborg: Obama Gets Reasonable on the Environment
summary: Yes to oil drilling, and to a World Bank loan for a coal plant.

headline: Hospital Attack Kills 9 in Quetta
summary: A suicide bomb attack outside a hospital emergency ward in the western border city of Quetta killed at least nine people Friday, including a television cameraman and two police officers.

headline: India Investigates Radiation Scare
summary: Indian authorities are investigating the origin of a radioactive substance that found its way into a New Delhi scrap metal shop, leaving six exposed people hospitalized.

headline: WHO Cites Risk If Ash Descends
summary: Europeans with respiratory conditions should stay indoors or take other precautions if substantial amounts of drifting ash from a volcanic eruption in Iceland start falling down to earth, the WHO said.

headline: Insurance Won't Cover Airlines' Losses
summary: Airlines, facing huge losses due to the volcanic ash cloud that has prevented aircraft from flying, won't be able to make claims to cover those losses because they aren't covered for such an event.

headline: Weinstein Enters Exclusive Talks for Miramax
summary: Walt Disney has entered into an exclusive window of negotiation for its Miramax Films unit with the Weinstein brothers, who founded the legendary independent movie studio and sold it to Disney in 1993.

headline: Custom-Fit Earphones
summary: Are custom-fit earphones worth the extra $100? Courtney Banks takes a second listen to Etymotic's noise-isolating earphones, this time using a pair made from a mold of her ears

headline: Apple Shuffles Directors' Roles
summary: Apple reshuffled several directors' board positions, putting the company back into compliance with its own rules after the sudden death last month of director Jerome York left it out of compliance.

headline: Toyota Recalls 600,000 Sienna Minivans Over Spare-Tire Cable
summary: Toyota announced a voluntary recall of about 600,000 Sienna minivans because the spare tire could potentially fall on the road and pose a hazard to other vehicles.

headline: Lawsuits Filed Against Massey Energy
summary: Two lawsuits were filed against Massey in the wake of the April 5 accident. The Labor Department has asked a team of occupational safety experts to examine the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration's internal review of its actions at the West Virginia mine.

headline: FDA Chides Glaxo for Cancer-Drug Ad
summary: The FDA on Friday said an advertisement for a Glaxo cancer drug and a Web site for a bladder treatment the company co-promotes were "false or misleading." The agency also took issue with a consumer email from Novartis about its pain gel Voltaren.

headline: Stocks Take Hit From Goldman Charge
summary: The Dow industrials sank 125.91 points as financials dropped in the wake of the Goldman fraud charge, though blue chips still gained for the week.

headline: IMF Prepared to Help Greece
summary: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Dominique Strauss-Kahn said the IMF is ready to provide one-third of any joint IMF-European financing package for Greece.

headline: Banker Says Fujitsu Scandal Imperils Fund
summary: The banker at the center of Fujitsu's feud with its former president says allegations by three of the company's directors that he has ties to organized crime could doom his investment fund.

headline: Japanese Bond Yields Decline
summary: Japanese government bond prices rose, pushing yields lower, as a stronger yen blurred the outlook for the country's export-driven economy, prodding investors to buy back safe-haven assets.

headline: Commodities Feel That Goldman Sting
summary: Oil, gold and sugar fell after the SEC charged Goldman Sachs, a large commodities trader, with fraud tied to subprime mortgages.

headline: AP Admits Rep. Heath Shuler Did Not Hear Tea Party Racial Slurs...After WSJ Writer Investigates
summary: From the Media Research Center

headline: Teatime at the Times
summary: It was difficult to find a story in the New York Times mentioning the Tea Partiers in which the words fear or anger didn't figure prominently.

headline: The New Stigma Is Luxury Goods
summary: The wealthy are recovering their fortunes, but they haven't recovered their love for luxury.

headline: Comcast-NBC Deadline Is Extended
summary: The FCC extended a deadline for comments on Comcast's deal to acquire controlling interest of NBC Universal.

headline: Economists Are Split Over Inflation
summary: Economists were evenly divided between those who fear inflation will accelerate over the next year and those who see a bigger risk that the inflation rate will slow, according to a WSJ forecasting survey.

headline: Goldman Charges Roil Markets
summary: Fraud charges against Goldman Sachs roiled financial markets, sending stocks and commodities tumbling and investors fleeing to the safety of Treasurys.

headline: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, First Federal Bancshares of Arkansas: Biggest Price Decliners (KKD, FFBH)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Goodyear Raises Truck Tire Prices
summary: Goodyear is increasing prices for commercial truck tires by up to 8% in North America, becoming the latest tire maker to pass along the rising cost of raw materials to its customers.

headline: European Stocks Feel Heat From Goldman; Thai Stocks Fall Again
summary: After closing Thursday at 18-months highs, the Stoxx Europe 600 index dropped 1.6% to 267.92. It remains up 5.5% for the year to date.

headline: Big, Stupid and Proud: Five Cars That Shook the Earth
summary: The period between 1992 and 2007 was a time of petroleum exuberance, and carmakers responded by creating a breed of gas-bonging mega-vehicles. It was, in fact, a kind of arms race to see who could build the most impractically large vehicle on the trembling road. Here's a few of the worst offenders.

headline: Inside the New Subaru Legacy
summary: Subaru's program for the 2010 Legacy sedan was to make it larger, to accommodate corn-fed Americans and to recalibrate the car's price point. But can it gain new customers without losing its flannel-shirt faithfuls? Here's a peek inside the new Subaru Legacy.

headline: Traders Flee From Gold
summary: Gold futures accelerated their fall following news that securities regulators charged Goldman Sachs and one of the bank's vice presidents with fraud.

headline: Pulling the Quick Fantasy Trigger
summary: A monstrous pitcher, an outfielder's renaissance and a new way to schedule opponents have spiced up the start of the 2010 fantasy baseball season.

headline: GE Leads U.S. Wind Market
summary: General Electric installed more wind-turbine capacity than rivals in the U.S. last year, but faces new competition from Asian companies.

headline: Oil Takes a Goldman Tumble
summary: Crude plunged 2.7% to $83.24 a barrel in a pan-market selloff following reports the investment bank had been charged by the SEC with defrauding investors.

headline: Week in Review
summary: View the top stories this week at OpinionJournal.com

headline: Help, My Credit is Wrecked!
summary: About to lose a home to foreclosure, a reader seeks advice on finding a landlord who will rent to someone with wrecked credit.

headline: Lincoln: Derivatives Bill to Provide '100% Transparency'
summary: Sen. Blanche Lincoln unveiled a proposal to regulate the over-the-counter derivatives market that is likely to draw the ire of Wall Street banks. Obama said he would veto any overhaul bill that doesn't regulate the derivatives market.

headline: Crist Agonistes
summary: Charlie Crist's decision to cave to teachers unions suggests he may run as an independent.

headline: The British Take on the Spin Room
summary: After party leaders got to grips with debating on TV, their lieutenants and journalists had to learn how to deal with the frantic amount of spin that comes after.

headline: Star Inspires Thai Demonstrators
summary: Continuing protests in Thailand Friday -- and the high-profile involvement of a pop star turned activist -- were the latest sign that the country's political and military hierarchy haven't yet come to terms with the scope and ingenuity of the Red Shirt protest movement.

headline: Keeping Track of Expenses on the Road
summary: It's no secret that one of the most mundane tasks on the planet is tracking and reporting business-travel expenses. Gina Hamadey, editor of "Every Day With Rachael Ray" magazine's travel section, shares some tips to spice up expense reporting.

headline: Dorfman to Join Securities-Industry Group
summary: Richard Dorfman, who resigned as chief executive officer of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Atlanta, will take a senior position at the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Associaton.

headline: Democrats Seek Tea Party, GOP Wedge
summary: A strategy memo shows the Obama administration and congressional Democrats hope to drive a wedge between tea-party activists and Republicans as part of the effort to secure passage of an increasingly partisan Wall Street measure.

headline: Renovation Picks Up Pace
summary: The work continues at breakneck speed at columnist Julia Angwin's brownstone. In the past three weeks, they've finished demolition, framing and floors.

headline: Entrepreneurs Doing Business by Avatar
summary: How to immerse yourself in a virtual world like Second Life.

headline: Singapore's Core Exports Jump
summary: Singapore's key exports rose at a faster than expected pace in March, driven by strong demand overseas for electronics and providing more support for the economy's sharp recovery.

headline: Documents Detail CIA Tape Destruction
summary: Top Central Intelligence Agency officials were concerned over whether it was proper to have destroyed videotapes showing the interrogation of terrorism suspects, according to internal documents released Thursday.

headline: Delivery Services Turn to Trucks
summary: Logistics services and express parcel operators in Europe have turned to trucks to keep delivery delays to a minimum and limit the impact of the air traffic disruption in northern Europe.

headline: Liverpool Owners Look to Sell Club
summary: Liverpool's American owners said they want to sell the debt-ridden Premier League club after three troubled years in charge.

headline: Iceland Volcano Disrupts Travel
summary: Fewer than half of Europe's regularly scheduled commercial flights were expected to take place Friday as many of the region's busiest routes will remain closed into Saturday as the fallout from a volcanic eruption in Iceland strandedt housands of travelers and has started to impact global trade.

headline: European Stocks Trade in Tight Range
summary: European stocks recovered from early losses, as investors reacted positively to healthy U.S. earnings but concerns over Greece's economic outlook continued to prompt cautious activity.

headline: Panasonic's Overseas Retrofit
summary: Panasonic says it wants a bigger piece of the overseas appliance market. The problem: Asian rivals have a jump on it in emerging markets, and the competition is already fierce.

headline: Euro-Zone Inflation Lower Than First Estimated
summary: Consumer prices in the 16 countries that use the euro rose at a slightly slower rate over the 12 months to March than first estimated, and the annual rate of inflation remained well below the European Central bank's target.

headline: First Horizon's Loss Narrows
summary: First Horizon National posted a narrower loss as its loan-loss provisions continued to decline.

headline: Elpida Upbeat on PC Chip Market
summary: Demand for memory chips from personal computer makers is very strong and global supply is likely to be lower than demand this year, the president and chief executive of Elpida Memory said.

headline: Regulator Suspends BHP-Rio Timetable
summary: Australia's competition regulator said Friday that it has suspended the timeline for its review of a proposed iron-ore joint venture between BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto.

summary: India's GSLV-D3 Rocket launch, Shashi Tharoor, Cyclone-hit West Bengal and Bihar and more.

headline: Euro, Greek Bonds Under Pressure
summary: The euro and Greek bond prices remained under pressure as EU officials began a regularly-scheduled meeting in Madrid with little indication that an aid package for Greece is imminent.

summary: Mahindra & Mahindra will buy out the 49% stake of partner Renault in the joint venture, Mahindra Renault, formed to make and sell the French car maker's Logan sedan in India, the two companies said.

headline: Too Big Not to Get Right
summary: The Dodd bill would make financial bailouts more likely.

headline: Asia Stocks Slump on Yen, China
summary: Asian markets fell Friday, with the Japanese yen's strength against major currencies weighing down shares of its exporters and as Chinese stocks were hurt by Beijing's move to curb property speculation.

headline: India Monsoon Seen Normal
summary: India's annual June-September monsoon rains are likely to be near normal levels, though more rainfall is expected after July due to the lingering effects of El Nino, a senior weather official with the state-run India Meteorological Department said.

summary: The Indian government has given an initial approval to low-fare carrier SpiceJet to fly overseas and is likely to allow within a month another budget airline to start international operations, a SpiceJet executive and a government official said.

summary: Reliance Industries and Deccan 360 announced that the Indian conglomerate has purchased a strategic stake for an undisclosed amount in the new express logistics company, started by the founder of India's first low-fare carrier.

headline: Pitcher Festival
summary: Snapshots from the Kumbh Mela (Pitcher Festival) in Haridwar, India. The Kumbh Mela is the world's largest religious festival that attracts a large crowd of devotees.

headline: Grounded Fleet to Cost BA Millions
summary: British Airways will see the cost of grounding its entire fleet for the first time in its history because of an ash plume from a volcano run to several millions of dollars.

headline: New Car Registrations Rise in Europe
summary: Registrations of new cars in Europe increased 11% on the year in March to 1.68 million vehicles, as state-backed scrapping incentive schemes in France, Italy, U.K. and Spain more than offset a 27% fall in Germany.

headline: Australia to Toughen Rules on Executive Pay
summary: The Australian government Friday unveiled plans to crack down on executive pay by promising to implement almost all of the recommendations of the Productivity Commission's report on corporate remuneration.

headline: North Korea's Radio Waves of Resistance
summary: The world's most isolated regime isn't so isolated anymore.

headline: Pyongyang Tipping Point
summary: Currency 'reform' sparked an economic crisis that the regime may not be able to repair.

headline: U.K. Fined Tobacco Firms, Retailers

headline: Swire Plans $3 Billion Property Spin-off

summary: Former housewives are bringing home the bacon in the Hermit Kingdom by being market vendors.

summary: China remained the largest foreign owner of Treasurys even as it reduced its holdings in February. Overall, foreigners were net buyers of long-term U.S. financial assets.

summary: Benjamin Vautier is gleefully stripping himself bare in a spectacular show at Lyon's Musée d'Art Contemporain, entitled "Ben Restrospective -- Strip-tease Intégral," featuring more than 1,200 artworks.

summary: New Zealand regulators filed criminal charges against four prominent New Zealanders over the collapse of a local financial firm that foundered when property prices there dropped sharply.

summary: With college tuition costs soaring, many students are chasing down obscure grants with requirements that are nonacademic, and sometimes bizarre. Among those in luck: students handy with duct tape.

summary: Ford is expected to post a sizable first-quarter profit after months of increased sales, market-share gains and stumbles by one of its chief competitors.

summary: An ex-intelligence agent was charged with 10 felony counts for alleged leaking classified Bush administration national- security information.

summary: There have been so many baseball games and so many pitches thrown that just about every unusual event that is reasonably likely to happen already has.

headline: Designer and Barneys Executive List
summary: Also in this column: Oilman Jerry Herbst offers his Newport Beach, Calif., home, and mining executive Richard Adkerson buys a ranch with two partners.

headline: Apache to Buy Mariner for $2.7 Billion
summary: Oil and gas producer Apache said it will acquire rival Mariner Energy for $2.7 billion to expand into deep-water areas of the Gulf of Mexico.

summary: Some edgy shows, such as "Fela!" and probably "American Idiot," are being shut out of an award category.

summary: More than 800 federal agents fanned out across Arizona and other states to dismantle a network that allegedly transported thousands of illegal immigrants from Mexico to the U.S.

summary: The earnings bounce-back has given banks the confidence to fight hard against reform in Washington. But not all the sins of the bubble will be forgotten quickly.

headline: Someone Check the Thunder's IDs
summary: The Oklahoma City Thunder are the youngest team ever to make it out of the regular season.

summary: Lawyers for black workers at a Turner Industries plant in Paris, Texas, say the EEOC found reasonable cause to believe charges of racial discrimination are true.

summary: The impact money-market-fund fee waivers are having was laid bare by Charles Schwab's results.

summary: The deal is expected to help the REIT pay down debt and relieve balance-sheet pressures. Some analysts think the funds may be used for acquisitions.

summary: Symphony Asset Management and Bank of America Merrill Lynch are teaming up on a new $500 million collateralized loan obligation, as the once-moribund structured debt vehicles continue their slow return to market.

summary: "Glee" star Jane Lynch talks about playing the hard-as-nails cheerleading coach on the hit show.

summary: Infections from a dangerous form of E. coli bacteria dropped significantly last year, in a sign new food-safety measures are starting to pay off.

summary: A series of blasts killed at least eight people and injured nearly 100 more in Myanmar's commercial center, Yangon, significantly increasing tensions in the run-up to national elections expected later this year.

summary: The choice of brothers Humberto and Fernando Campana to inaugurate Waddesdon Manor, a stately home in South East England, is an acknowledgment of their current status as two of the world's most favored designers.

summary: A scathing report by a U.N. commission investigating the assassination of former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto blasted Pakistani authorities for failing to protect her and for destroying evidence after the attack.

headline: Third-Party Candidate Shines in U.K. Debate
summary: Britain's first televised debate produced few major domestic policy differences between the two top candidates, opening the door for a third-party candidate.

headline: Strassel: The Greens' Ground Zero
summary: A rural Republican is targeted by the environmental left.

summary: Greece edged closer to a bailout, asking the EU and IMF to begin "discussions" on aid, as its cost of borrowing from private markets continued to rise and the euro tumbled.

summary: Lagardère's CEO said he won't bend to demands from a U.S.-based activist investor to give shareholders a greater say in company management.

headline: Bieito's 'Parsifal': Bloody Mayhem, Spiritual Longing
summary: Spanish director Calixto Bieito brings his cabinet of bloody props to Stuttgart's Staatsoper, where he is staging a sexy, superb new production of "Parsifal," Richard Wagner's 5 1/2 hour swan song of chastity and redemption.

headline: Taken With Tamil Nadu
summary: India's Tamil Nadu state finally has some higher-end lodgings to go along with its remarkable temples.

headline: PC Market Rebounds in Quarter
summary: Global PC shipments rebounded strongly in the first quarter according to a pair of research reports, pointing to the beginning of a long-awaited replacement cycle.

headline: UPS, 3M, Intel Rise, H-P Falls
summary: Stocks climbed to nearly 19-month highs, led by industrial companies.

headline: NASA Plan Fails to Appease Critics
summary: Obama defended his plan to outsource NASA functions and sketched out a timetable for deep space exploration.

headline: Time Off
summary: "Grace Kelly: Style Icon" at the Victoria and Albert Museum, shows outfits worn by Grace Kelly during her Hollywood career as well as Princess Grace of Monaco ensembles.

headline: Global Cricket Is a Sticky Wicket
summary: The Indian Premier League, the megabucks domestic Twenty20 tournament that's transforming cricket, is already the subject of hugely entertaining hype and bluster. But one of the most potentially far-reaching developments, announced just before the competition started, has slipped under the radar: The teams are going global.

headline: Factory Output Surged 0.9% Last Month
summary: U.S. manufacturing output surged in March as factories continued to lead the economic recovery, while a key gauge of housing-sector sentiment benefited from a federal tax credit due to expire this month.
